Send a text Mon to Fri from 9 to 5, or text LIBRARY for info.

actions.text:
Hello, you have reached HealthJam. 

We cannot take your call. 

Please send us a text message and we will call you back. Good day!

HealthJam: Welcome to HealthJam! 
Please SAVE this number in your contacts  as 'HealthJam' so you know it is HealthJam when we text you.

HealthJam: What time should we send texts?  Think about when you'll have this phone & time to reply.

1 - morning at 7am
2 - lunch at 12pm
3 - night at  8pm

HealthJam Error: Please choose the time you would like texts. Please enter

1 - to get texts at 7am 

2 - to get texts at 12pm

3 - to get texts at 8pm

You can text
SETTINGS > to change the time of texts
LIBRARY > to view a library of health information. 
You can also send a text anytime to chat with HealthJam

actions.text:
HealthJam SETTINGS
1 - SHARE an idea 
2 - CHANGE time for texts
3 - OPT OUT or STOP texts
99 - EXIT Settings menu
We understand you want to stop receiving some automatic HealthJam texts. Please talk to the HealthJam team to opt out.

HealthJam - What time should we send texts? 
1 - mornings @ 7am
2 - lunch @ 12pm
3 - night @ 8pm

HealthJam IDEAS
We value your input & ideas to improve HealthJam. Please text us your ideas. 
- Have a joke or motivational message idea? 
- Have tips for how to improve HealthJam? 
Text us now. Thank you!!

actions.body:

actions.text: {HealthJam} Thank you very much for sharing your idea. Have a great day and text if HealthJam can support.
HealthJam - Great, HealthyJam will send you messages at 7am. To change again, text SETTINGS. Have a good day.
HealthJam - Great, HealthyJam will send you messages at 12pm.To change again, text SETTINGS. Have a good day.
HealthJam - Great, HealthyJam will send you messages in the evenings at 8pm. To change again, text SETTINGS. Have a good day.

HealthJam: Hello, HealthJam checking in. How are you doing? 
Please reply
1 - if you are fantastic, great
2 - if you are not so great

Sorry, I do not understand. 
How are you? Please reply with the number
1 - if you are fantastic
2 - if you are not so great
HealthJam: Glad you're feeling fantastic. Please text HealthJam with any questions or type LIBRARY to access the library. Have a great week!

HealthJam: Sorry to hear you're not great. Do you want to talk? 
1 - YES, call me as soon as you can
2 - NO, do not call me
HealthJam: Okay, we will call you as soon as we can. While you wait, you can text LIBRARY to access the HealthJam Health Library.
HealthJam: Your request to NOT be called has been noted. You can text LIBRARY to see the Health library. Wishing you a good day.

- HealthJam - HIV
Let's talk about HIV.
1 - WHAT IS HIV?
2 - PREVENTION

- HealthLibrary - SUGAR
Diabetes, also called 'sugar', is the 2nd leading cause of death for Jamaicans under 70 years.
#1
The body is not able to use sugar eaten in meals, so sugar builds up to a high level that can cause damage to the kidneys, eyes, nerves, and heart. #2

QUESTION: What is Diabetes?
- Diabetes is a condition in which the body does not properly process food for use as energy. 
#3

- This causes sugar to build up in your blood. This is why many people call diabetes "sugar". Diabetes affects all age groups.
#4

QUESTION: What are some signs of diabetes?
- Increased hunger, thirst & urination
- Slow healing wounds
- Blurred vision
- Extreme tiredness
#5

- Itching all over the body
- Cuts that take long to heal
- Repeat infections like Yeast or urine infections
- Weight gain or weight loss
- Impotence
#6

QUESTION: Is having diabetes serious?
Yes. Diabetes can cause problems, like a stroke or heart attack, loss of limbs, blindness, hearing & sexual problems
#7

QUESTION: Does having diabetes mean I can't have any sweet or sugary foods ?
Persons with diabetes should eat a healthy diet & and can have some sugar. 
#8

If you have diabetes, your health care provider will tell you how much of each type of food you can eat
#9

QUESTION: How do people get diabetes? Can I catch it from someone who has it?
The most common way to get diabetes is making unhealthy food choices such as...
10

...fast food on a regular basis as well as not getting enough exercise.
It is not possible to catch diabetes from another person.
#11

Some persons get diabetes when they are young (under 25 years). This is usually because their body doesn't make the hormone to use up the sugar in the blood. 
#12

QUESTION: How do people find out if they have diabetes?
You can visit your health care provider to get a form to go to a lab to have a blood test done.
#13

The tests will check how much sugar is in your blood before your first meal in the morning and then how much sugar is in the blood 2 hours after eating.  
#14

QUESTION: Is there treatment for diabetes?
Yes, a health care provider will advise the best way to treat diabetes after an exam and looking at test results. 
#15

The health care provider will explain what foods are best to eat, how much exercise will help and will give a prescription for medication if it is needed. 
#16

QUESTION: Can I take herbal medicine or drink bush tea to treat diabetes?
No. Some herbal medicines and bush tea might cause the diabetes to get worse. 
#17

If you have diabetes, it's best to get advice from a health care provider.
#18

Diabetes can only be treated with medication from a health care provider along with healthy eating & exercise.
#19

QUESTION: If I have diabetes, will I have to inject myself everyday?
Not all persons with diabetes need the injection medication called insulin. 
#20

Some persons will only take tablets, eat healthy and exercise while some persons will only need to eat healthy and exercise. 
#21

QUESTION: Will I eventually get blind or lose a leg if I have diabetes?
Eating healthy, exercising & medication will decrease the chance of these complications.

QUESTION: My health care provider says my sugar is controlled. Does that mean I am cured and can stop the medication? 
No. It does not mean you are cured. #23

Some people can control their blood sugar without medicine by losing weight, eating a healthy diet, and getting regular exercise. 
#24

But if you have been depending on the medicine to control you will likely have to continue.
#25

Get Sugar Screening!
- Text HealthJam with questions
- Contact your health care provider
#26

- Take 'Wellness Check" at https://ncdip.moh.gov.jm/ 
- Call 888-ONE-LOVE (663-5693)
#27
-HealthJam- We have given a lot of information. Contact your health care provider with questions. You can delete these texts & get them back by texting LIBRARY to this number. Have a great day!

- HealthJam - ABOUT
HealthJam is a new service from the Ministry of Health & Wellness that aims to connect Jamaicans to health information and care through text messaging services.
Text HealthJam questions about your health, & we'll do our best to reply in a timely manner. For some questions, it's best to chat by phone so we may call you!

- HealthLibrary- NUTRITION
Jamaica has under & over nutrition. Continuous poor eating habits can lead to diseases like hypertension, diabetes, & cancer.

FIVE TIPS on healthy eating:
1. Eat a variety of foods from all the food groups daily
2. Eat a variety of fruits and vegetables daily

3. Reduce intake of salty and processed foods daily
4. Reduce intake of fats and oils
5. Reduce intake of sugary foods and drink

For more information, please visit 
https://www.moh.gov.jm/edu-resources/food-based-dietary-guidelines-for-jamaica/
- HealthJam - Info overload? Delete the messages and you can get them back by texting LIBRARY to this number.
Exiting HealthJam HealthLibrary. Text LIBRARY anytime to access this resource. Thanks and have a great day.

-HealthLibrary - U=U
QUESTION: What does U=U mean?

U=U means that people with HIV who achieve and maintain an undetectable viral load (the amount of HIV in the blood) by taking antiretroviral therapy (ART) daily as prescribed cannot sexually transmit the virus to others.
QUESTION: If I have an undetectable viral load, do my partner and I need to use anything else to prevent sexual transmission of HIV?

- Use condoms to help prevent other sexually transmitted infections.
- Use condoms or have your partner take PrEP to provide additional peace of mind

- Consider using additional options if you are (1)unsure of your viral load result, (2) have trouble taking HIV medicine regularly, (3) missed some doses of your HIV medicine since your last viral load test, or (4) have stopped taking HIV medicine or may do so in the future

-HealthJam- We have given a lot of information. Please contact your health care provider with questions. You can delete these texts and get them back by texting LIBRARY to this number. Have a great day!

- HealthLibrary - HIV Care SUPPORT SERVICES
People living with HIV have many support services available.

~~ JN+ ~~
JN+ provides support to the community of People living with HIV through capacity building projects/programmes using our Positive Health Dignity Prevention curriculum (PHDP). JN+ receives complaints of HIV-related stigma and discrimination and other human rights violations against persons living with HIV. 
https://www.myjnplus.org/

~~ JASL ~~
JASL aims to be a world class leader creating and utilizing best practices in the delivery of services to persons living with and affected by HIV and AIDS in Jamaica and participating in the fight against the spread of HIV and AIDS in Jamaica in an enabling environment.
https://jasforlife.org/

-HealthJam- We have given a lot of information. Please contact your health care provider with questions. You can delete these texts and get them back by texting LIBRARY to this number. Have a great day!

-HealthLibrary - PrEP
QUESTION: What is PrEP?

Pre Exposure Prophylaxis or PrEP is a way for people who do NOT have HIV but who are at very high risk of getting HIV to prevent HIV infection by taking a pill every day.
When taken daily, PrEP is highly effective for preventing HIV. PrEP is not effective if it is not taken consistently.
As PrEP only protects against HIV, condoms are important for the protection against other Sexually Transmitted Infections.
Talk to your healthcare provider to learn more about PrEP.

-HealthJam- We have given a lot of information. Please contact your health care provider with questions. You can delete these texts and get them back by texting LIBRARY to this number. Have a great day!

-HealthJam - Care Team - 
QUESTION: Who is part of the HIV care team?
A multidisciplinary team supports HIV care. This means many healthcare workers work together to ensure that physical, mental, and social needs are addressed.

The HIV treatment care and support team include... 
Healthcare Providers
Nurses
Psychologists
Social Workers
Case Managers
Contact Investigators

Adherence Counselors, and
Community Facilitators.

- HealthJam - HIV 
Let's talk about HIV.

QUESTION: What is HIV?
HIV is a virus that attacks our cells that help the body fight infection (called CD4 cells), killing these cells.
This makes a person with HIV infection more open to other viral and bacterial infections & diseases.
HIV stands for Human Immunodeficiency Virus and if the infection with this virus is untreated it causes AIDS or Acquired Immune Deficiency syndrome.
You cannot have AIDS without being infected with HIV but many HIV infected persons who are on treatment live long and healthy lives and do not develop AIDS.
There is no cure for HIV, but HIV medicines help persons stay healthy and prevent the virus from being passed to others when the "viral load" is undetectable

QUESTION: How do I get HIV?
HIV virus is carried in secretions from the genitals (vaginal fluids, cum), anal mucus, blood and breast milk.
> SEX: It is a sexually transmitted infection and most people become infected through sexual contact, vaginal or anal.
> BLOOD: It can also be spread by contact with infected blood or from mother to child during pregnancy, childbirth or breastfeeding.
Sharing needles or syringes for piercings, tattoos or injecting drugs may also pass on the HIV virus

QUESTION: What is a 'Window Period'?
When a person gets infected it may take 6 weeks or up to 3 months before antibodies to HIV are detected in the blood.
The HIV test looks for antibodies. When these antibodies are detected the person is diagnosed HIV positive.
A person can be positive AND the test shows negative because the test was done during the window period. It is important to be tested regularly for HIV.

QUESTION: What are the symptoms of HIV & AIDS?
It may be many years after infection with the HIV virus before the infected person begins to feel sick.

Because of this many people do not know they are infected unless they do a HIV test. 
When symptoms start they may be mild...
When symptoms start they may be mild -- like a flu-achy feeling, fevers, chills, tiredness, a sore throat or rash.
... like a flu-achy feeling, fevers, chills, tiredness, a sore throat or rash. During this period there is A LOT OF VIRUS in the body...
...and it can be spread to sexual partners through unprotected sex. Even without these symptoms - whether or not you feel sick, HIV can be spread to others.

QUESTION: What are the stages of HIV infection? 
- STAGE 1 - ACUTE INFECTION
- STAGE 2 - LATENCY
- STAGE 3 - ADVANCED HIV or AIDS:
STAGE 1 - ACUTE INFECTION: When a person gets infected with HIV, it multiplies very rapidly - "acute Infection." Most people will have mild flu-like symptoms...
...within 2 to 6 weeks after being infected. Some have no symptoms or don't recall any. The risk of transmitting the virus at this stage is very high
STAGE 2 - LATENCY: The virus quietly and slowly multiplies - "clinical latency". In this stage, a patient may have no signs/symptoms.
This latent period can last for 2 to more than 10 years, and here the immune system is still strong. People CAN STILL INFECT others with HIV during this stage.
STAGE 3 - ADVANCED HIV or AIDS: The virus damages certain organs and the general immune system following rapid replication of the virus
By damaging the immune system, HIV interferes with the body's ability to fight organisms that cause disease.  So, an HIV infected person is more likely...
... to develop opportunistic infections or cancers. By "opportunistic", we mean diseases that wouldn't usually trouble a person with a healthy immune system.

QUESTION: Can HIV be cured? 
No, HIV is a chronic, life-long condition.
However, with consistent medication & self care, the life expectancy for people living with HIV can be almost the same as HIV-negative individuals.

QUESTION: What is the treatment for HIV? 
Treatment will help you stay healthy even though it does not cure HIV.
Antiretroviral therapy (ART) is a combination of medicines, often in a single pill, that suppresses the HIV virus but does not completely get rid of it.
This allows HIV infected persons who take their meds as prescribed to live long and healthy lives,
...and when the virus is fully suppressed (viral load is undetectable) they will not infect others.

QUESTION: What if I think I have been exposed to HIV?
Go to your healthcare provider to make a plan.
There is medicine that can prevent HIV transmission in HIV-negative people who have been exposed to HIV called post-exposure prophylaxis, or PEP.

QUESTION: What is the HIV test & where can I get it? 
Getting tested for HIV is the only way to know if you have HIV.
Testing is quick and easy, all that is required is a drop of your blood for the rapid test that can give you your result in less than 30 minutes.
The HIV test can be done at any health centre and in some healthcare providers offices.
Other great places to get tested include AHF & JASL sites in Kingston, St Ann and Montego Bay.

QUESTION: WHO SHOULD GET TESTED? 
If you are having unprotected (no condom) sex, routine testing is advised.
If your partner tests positive for HIV or if you have shared needles with anyone either for taking drugs or tattooing or piercing then testing is advised.

QUESTION: What HIV tests are the most accurate? 
HIV tests are all very accurate at detecting HIV, but every HIV test has a window period.
The window period is the time between exposure to HIV and when a test can detect HIV.

Here are three types of HIV tests:
> RAPID TEST
> COMBINATION HIV TEST
> NUCLEIC ACID TEST
- RAPID HIV TEST: A rapid HIV test is a fingerstick blood test that gives results in less than a few minutes.
Rapid HIV tests are sometimes called antibody tests because the test looks for antibodies in your blood. Antibodies are produced by...
... your immune system when you have been exposed to HIV. The window period for a rapid test is generally 90 days but can vary from person to person.
- COMBINATION HIV TEST: A combination HIV test is a blood test that gives results in less than a week.
It looks for both HIV antibodies and antigens. Antigens are foreign substances that cause your immune system to activate.
This means that this test will have a shorter window period and is generally 45 days after infection but can also vary between individuals.
- NUCLEIC ACID TEST:  A nucleic acid test is a blood test that gives results in less than a week
A nucleic acid test is sometimes called a viral load test.
This test is used to confirm an HIV infection. It is not routinely used unless an individual has a positive rapid HIV test or positive combination HIV test.

-HealthJam- We have given a lot of information. Please contact your health care provider with questions. You can delete these texts and get them back by texting LIBRARY to this number. Have a great day!
-HealthLibrary - HIV PREVENTION

QUESTION: Are condoms an effective way of preventing sexually transmitted infections like HIV for people who are sexually active?
Yes.
Condoms have been proven to provide protection against sexually transmitted infections (STIs).
FACT: condoms are the only method that can prevent both pregnancy and STIs.

QUESTION: I am HIV positive. How do I protect my sexual partners?
#1 TIP: The #1 way to protect sexual partners is to Get and Keep an Undetectable Viral Load
If you take HIV medicine and get and keep an undetectable viral load, this will significantly reduce the risk of HIV transmission to your sex partner.
Getting and keeping an undetectable viral load is the best thing you can do to stay healthy and protect others.

QUESTION: If I'm HIV positive and I DON'T have an undetectable viral load, how do I protect my partners?
Stick to your treatment plan.
A few people cannot get an undetectable viral load even though they take HIV medicine as prescribed.
If your viral load is not undetectable-or does not stay undetectable-you can still protect your partners by using other prevention options.

-TIP #2 - PrEP pill
Encourage Your Partners to Take PrEP. PrEP (pre-exposure prophylaxis) is medicine people at risk for HIV take to prevent HIV.
If taken as prescribed, PrEP is highly effective for preventing HIV from sex and injection drug use. Talk to your healthcare provider to learn more about PrEP.

TIP #3 - CONDOMS 
Use Condoms the Right Way Every Time You Have Sex. Condoms are highly effective in preventing HIV & other sexually transmitted Infections
Use water-based or silicone-based lubricants to help prevent condoms from breaking or slipping during sex.
Speak to your healthcare provider about the right way to use condoms and ask where you can get free supplies of condoms and lubricants.

TIP #4 - Avoid high risk sexual activities.
Choose Sexual Activities with Little to No Risk. For example, there is little to no risk of getting HIV through oral sex.
Avoid rough sex that might cause bruises and irritations e.g. Daggering.
Use lube. You can't transmit HIV through sexual activities that don't involve contact with body fluids (semen, vaginal fluid, or blood).

TIP #5 - GET TESTED & TREATED FOR OTHER STIS
If you get & keep an undetectable viral load, getting an STI...
... does NOT appear to increase the risk of transmitting HIV. But STIs can cause other problems.
If you have a detectable viral load, getting tested & treated for other STIs can help lower your chances of transmitting HIV.
TIP #6 ENCOURAGE YOUR PARTNERS TO GET TESTED.

QUESTION:  I am HIV positive. How can I protect my baby?

TIP #1 - LEARN ABOUT MEDICATIONS 
TIP #2 - DON'T BREASTFEED YOUR BABY

TIP #1 - LEARN ABOUT MEDICATIONS 
Your healthcare provider will order tests and suggest medicine for you to take.
Discuss all the pros and cons of taking medicine while you're pregnant. Ask your healthcare provider questions about other antenatal care and family planning.

Take HIV Medicine as Prescribed and Give HIV Medicine to Your Baby After Birth. 
Treatment will not change much from what it was before you became pregnant.
If you take HIV medicine as prescribed throughout pregnancy, labour, & delivery AND give HIV medicine to your baby for 4 to 6 weeks after birth...
... then your baby's risk of getting HIV can be 1% or less. This is very very low.

TIP #2 - DON'T BREASTFEED YOUR BABY
Do not breastfeed your baby, even if you have an undetectable viral load.
Having an undetectable viral load reduces the risk of transmitting HIV to the baby through breastfeeding but doesn't eliminate the risk.

Talk with a social worker now about receiving free formula for your baby after delivery.
TALK TO YOUR HEALTHCARE PROVIDER about care for you and your baby.
QUESTION: If I am HIV positive and if I have an undetectable viral load, do my partner and I need to use anything else to prevent sexual transmission of HIV?
Getting & keeping an undetectable viral load prevents HIV transmission during sex.
BUT THERE ARE SITUATIONS when you may want to use additional prevention options.

- Use condoms to help prevent other sexually transmitted infections.
- Use condoms or have your partner take PrEP to provide additional peace of mind
- Consider using additional options if you are...

(1)unsure of your viral load result, 
(2) have trouble taking HIV medicine regularly,

(3) missed some doses of your HIV medicine since your last viral load test, or 
(4) have stopped taking HIV medicine or may do so in the future

QUESTION: Why is it important to use condoms even if my partner is also HIV positive?
Condoms are important to protect against other Sexually Transmitted Infections & pregnancy.
Condoms also helps prevent to the sexual transmission of HIV Drug Resistance between partners.

-HealthJam- We have given a lot of information. Please contact your health care provider with questions. You can delete these texts and get them back by texting LIBRARY to this number. Have a great day!

- HealthJam - STARTING HIV MEDICINE 
ART (Antiretroviral Therapy/Treatment) is the use of HIV medicines (ARV) to treat HIV infection,...
... suppress the virus and stop the progression of the HIV virus.
If a person takes ART daily and stays in care, the life expectancy for people living with HIV has been shown to be almost the same as HIV-negative individuals.

GOALS OF ART (long version)
- Suppress the virus and restore the immune system 
- Improve the quality of life and clinical outcome

- Treat the complicating illnesses
- Minimize the risk of resistance and toxicity
- TREAT THE WHOLE PERSON, not just the diseases they have
- DECREASE the chance of transmission to another person when someone has an undetectable viral load - treatment as prevention
- Prevent HIV transmission in HIV-negative people who are at high risk of being exposed to HIV (with pre-exposure prophylaxis, or PrEP)
- Prevent HIV transmission in HIV-negative people who have been exposed to HIV (post-exposure prophylaxis, or PEP)

GOALS OF ART (the short version)
Goal to decrease the amount of HIV in the blood (typically until viral load is less than 50 copies or 'undetectable')

THIS
Preserves immune system (so immune functions increases)
AND LEADS TO A
Long and healthy life

BENEFIT OF ADHERENCE:
The goal of ART is to move the viral load down, ideally to undetectable levels.
In general, a person's viral load will be declared "undetectable" if it is under 50 copies in a sample of a person's blood (although the exact number depends on the test and lab).

HAVING AN UNDETECTABLE VIRAL LOAD
- Allows the immune system to recover and become stronger.
- Puts a person at very low risk of becoming ill because of HIV.

- Reduces a person's risk of developing other serious illnesses.
- The risk of HIV becoming resistant to the anti-HIV drugs a person is taking is very small.
- Reduces the risk of passing on HIV to someone else.

QUESTION: What is ART Adherence ?
The ability to take all medications as prescribed:
- The right drugs
- Stored under the right condition

- The right dosage
- The right time
- In the right way
HealthJam: Info overload? Delete the messages and you can get them back by texting LIBRARY to this number.

- HealthLibrary - TAKING HIV MEDS
HIV is a life-long disease & the way to stay healthy is taking antiretrovirals (ART) daily.
It's important to regularly visit a health center to receive lifelong care & treatment.

GOALS OF ART (long version)
- Suppress the virus and restore the immune system 
- Improve the quality of life and clinical outcome

- Treat the complicating illnesses
- Minimize the risk of resistance and toxicity
- TREAT THE WHOLE PERSON, not just the diseases they have

-HealthLibrary - BLOOD TESTS
QUESTION: What is the viral load & how can it be undetectable? 
Viral load is the term used to describe the amount of HIV in a person's blood.
The higher the viral load, the quicker a person's immune system will be damaged,
increasing their chances of catching infections that the body would normally fight off very easily and increases the risk of transmission to a sexual partner.
ART if taken consistently lowers the amount of virus in the body and the number of viral cells found in each milliliter(ml) of blood.
This amount of viral particles is called the viral load and when on treatment the number can go so low that it can no longer be detected by standard tests.
This is described as an undetectable viral load. When someone on regular treatment becomes undetectable & remains that way ...
...viral load testing is unable to detect the virus, they will not spread HIV to others during sex.
QUESTION: What is an undetectable viral load?
A person living with HIV is considered to have an 'undetectable' viral load when...
... antiretroviral treatment has brought the level of virus in their body to such low levels that a regular blood test cannot detect it.
This does NOT mean that HIV has been cured. An undetectable viral load does not mean the person no longer has the HIV infection.
It means that the ART is successfully suppressing the virus but HIV is still present in the body ...
...and will come roaring back if the person falls out of care or stops taking their medication regularly as prescribed.

QUESTION: Do I still have to take HIV Medication If my viral load Is undetectable?
Yes, antiretroviral therapy (ART) reduces your viral load...
..., ideally to an undetectable level. If your viral load goes down after starting ART, then the treatment is working...
..., and you should continue to take your medicine as prescribed. If you keep an undetectable viral load, you can stay healthy.

QUESTION: What does viral suppression mean?
The terms viral suppression and undetectable viral load are used interchangeably to mean the same thing.
This is when antiretroviral drugs (ARvs) reduces a person's viral load to an undetectable level.
Viral suppression does NOT mean a person is cured; HIV still remains in the body.
If ARVs are discontinued, the person's viral load will likely return to a detectable level and they will no longer be virally suppressed.

QUESTION: What does CD4 mean?
CD4 cells are white blood cells that play an important role in the immune system.
A CD4 cell count gives an indication of the health of your immune system - a body's natural defense system against pathogens, infections and illnesses.

QUESTION: What is a CD4 Count?
A CD4 cell count is the number of blood cells in a very small blood sample.

- HealthJam - VIRAL LOAD
A viral load count is a lab test that measures the number of HIV particles in a milliliter of blood. These viral particles are called "copies."
A viral load test helps provide information about the progression of the virus in the patient's blood and how well antiretroviral therapy is controlling the virus.

THE GOAL OF ART
The goal of ART is to move the viral load down, ideally to undetectable levels. In general, a person's viral load will be declared "undetectable" if it is under 50 copies in a sample of blood (although the exact number depends on the test and lab).

HAVING AN UNDETECTABLE VIRAL LOAD
- Allows the immune system to recover and become stronger.
- Puts you at very low risk of becoming ill because of HIV. 
- Reduces risk of developing some other serious illnesses.
- The risk of HIV becoming resistant to the anti-HIV drugs you are taking is very small.
- Reduces the risk of passing on HIV to someone else.

Viral load monitoring is the preferred lab test for monitoring the success of ART.
Viral load should be measured every 6 to 12 months after ART initiation and annually thereafter.

-HealthJam- We have given a lot of information. Please contact your health care provider with questions. You can delete these texts and get them back by texting LIBRARY to this number. Have a great day!
- DECREASE the chance of transmission to another person when someone has an undetectable viral load - treatment as prevention
- Prevent HIV transmission in HIV-negative people who are at high risk of being exposed to HIV (with pre-exposure prophylaxis, or PrEP)
- Prevent HIV transmission in HIV-negative people who have been exposed to HIV (post-exposure prophylaxis, or PEP)

GOALS OF ART (the short version)
Goal to decrease the amount of HIV in the blood (typically until viral load is less than 50 copies or 'undetectable')

THIS
Preserves immune system (so immune functions increases)
AND LEADS TO A
Long and healthy life

QUESTION: What is ART Adherence ?
The ability to take all medications as prescribed:
- The right drugs
- Stored under the right condition

- The right medication dosage (amount)
- The right time
- In the right way
QUESTION: What can I do to reduce common side effects of HIV Medications?

- FEELING NAUSEOUS? 
Salted crackers
Mint/ginger tea
Ginger ale
Ginger beer
Pepsi/sprite (room temperature)

- HAVE UPSET STOMACH?
Mint/ginger tea
Ginger ale
Less sugary drink

- OVERALL TIPS?
Drink clear fluid frequently.
Avoid greasy foods.
Eat a small snack before taking an ARV e.g a cracker or piece of fruit to open the pallet, this will allow you to swallow a tablet with little to no complication.
Document any effect before and after taking ARV and share with an Adherence Counselor.

QUESTION: What are some tips to make pill swallowing easier?
TIP #1: Pop-bottle method
TIP #2: Lean forward method

TIP #1: Pop-bottle method
1. Fill a plastic bottle with water.
2. Put the tablet on the tongue and close lips tightly around the bottle opening.
3. Take a drink, keeping contact between the bottle and lips by pursing lips and using a sucking motion to swallow the water and pill.

TIP #2: Lean forward method
1. Put the capsule on the tongue and take a medium sip of water - do not swallow yet.

2. Bend the head forward by tilting chin slightly toward your chest.
3. Swallow the capsule and the water with the head bent forward.

-HealthJam- We have given a lot of information. Please contact your health care provider with questions. You can delete these texts and get them back by texting LIBRARY to this number. Have a great day!
It is not a count of all the CD4 cells in the body. A higher CD4 count indicates a stronger immune system.
- The CD4 cell count of a person who does not have HIV can be anything between 500 and 1500.
- People living with HIV who have a CD4 count over 500 are usually in pretty good health.
- People living with HIV who have a CD4 cell count below 200 have AIDS and are at high risk of developing serious illnesses.
HIV treatment is recommended for all people living with HIV. It is especially important for people with low CD4 counts.

- HealthLibrary - PRESSURE
Hypertension, traditionally called 'Pressure', is a leading cause of illness and death in Jamaica.
#1

QUESTION: What causes Hypertension?
Just as too much water pressure can damage pipes & faucets, high blood pressure causes blood to be pressured in the body. #2

QUESTION: Do some foods make pressure worse?
Foods with high salt like fast food, canned food & drinks like alcohol can make it harder to control pressure. 
#3

QUESTION: Does coffee make pressure worse?
No, coffee does not make pressure worse.
#4

QUESTION: Are you at risk of getting Hypertension?
Common risk factors include:
> aging
> family history of pressure
> physical inactivity
#5

> unhealthy eating
> overweight or obesity
> excess alcohol intake
> smoking
> stress
#6

QUESTION: Is it true that if pressure runs in my family there is nothing I can do to prevent it?
Healthy choices like exercising 30 min, 5 times a week...
#7

...and avoiding fast foods can help persons to prevent getting pressure, even if many close family members like their parents have it. 
#8

QUESTION: I checked my pressure at a pharmacy and was told it is high. Does that mean I have to start taking medication?
#9

- It is best to see your healthcare provider who will check your pressure after you have been sitting for 10 minutes or more. 
#10

-If you get several high readings on different days then it is likely that you have pressure
#11

- Your health care provider will decide if you need to start medication or if it is best to change your diet, exercise and lose weight first.
#12

QUESTION: Does pressure only affect old people?
It is more common in older people. However, it can affect younger persons...
#13
... if they are obese or due to some other types of illnesses. So it's still important to have your pressure checked even if you are young. #14

QUESTION: What are the symptoms of pressure?
It's called the "silent killer" b/c persons with high blood pressure USUALLY DON'T HAVE ANY SYMPTOMS or pain 
#15

Symptoms of very high blood pressure include:
> Severe headaches
> Nosebleed
> Fatigue or confusion
> Vision problems
> Chest pain
#16

> Difficulty breathing
> Irregular heartbeat
> Blood in the urine 
This is a medical emergency.
#17

QUESTION: Can I take herbal medicine or drink bush tea to cure high blood pressure?
No. ...
#18

High blood pressure can only be treated with medication prescribed by a health care provider combined with healthy eating habits and exercise. 
#19

Some herbal medicines & bush tea might cause the high blood pressure to get worse. It is best to get advice from a health care provider. 
#20

QUESTION: Do I still have to eat healthy and exercise if my health care provider gives me blood pressure tablets?
#21

A healthy diet and exercise is important for everyone. 
#22

Even those without any illnesses. It is even more important when you have an illness like pressure as it helps to control the illness.
#23

QUESTION: Can I stop taking pressure tablets when my blood pressure comes down or if I don't feel sick? 
#24

Pressure is a lifelong illness. Medications do not cure hypertension. If you stop taking your medications, then your blood pressure will rise again
#25

Get Pressure Screening!
> Talk to your health care provider
- Take 'Wellness Check" at https://ncdip.moh.gov.jm/ 
- Call 888-ONE-LOVE (663-5693)
#26

- HealthLibrary - SAFER SEX
Good sex is safe sex. 
Let's talk about it.
#1

SAFER SEX means being responsible about sexual activities in order to protect yourself from unplanned pregnancies & sexually transmitted infections.
#2

QUESTION: WHAT IS SAFE SEX?
We say 'safer' because once you are sexually active, no method is 100% safe. 
#3

Using both a condom AND another contraceptive method (like birth control pills) is considered the ULTIMATE WAY to have Safer Sex.
#4

QUESTION: How can I have safer sex? 
> Use condoms every time you have sex
#5

> Use contraceptives like the pill to prevent pregnancy. 
> Limit the number of partners you have
#6

DON'T HAVE SEX IF:
> Condoms are not available
> Under the influence
> If you have a Sexually Transmitted Infection (STI) that is not yet treated. 
#7

DO:
> Get regularly tested for STIs (both you & your partners)
> Take your HIV or STI medications as your health care provider advises.
#8

> Encourage your sexual partners to get tested and treated as well to prevent re-infection.
> Talk with your health care provider or Contact Investigator! 
#9

QUESTION: What are my options for contraceptive methods (like birth control pills)? 
Talk to your health care provider. 
#10

You can also visit https://jnfpb.org/sex-your-health/contraceptives/ 
#11

QUESTION: Are CONDOMS the only effective way of preventing STIs?
YES! Condoms are proven to provide protection against sexually transmitted infections
#12

Condoms are the ONLY method for STI protection AND contraception! 
The ULTIMATE WAY to be SAFER? Use a condom AND another contraceptive (dual method) #13

QUESTION: Where can I get FREE screening for STIs?
Visit https://jnfpb.org/hiv-test-family-planning/ or go to your nearest health clinic. #14

- HealthLibrary - STIs
Let's talk about Sexually Transmitted Infections or STIs. 
STIs are serious and can cause major health problems. 
#1

QUESTION; Where can I get information about STIs?
Talk with your healthcare provider, Nurse, Midwife or Contact Investigator to get information about STIs.
#2

QUESTION: Where can I get condoms?
Most health clinics provide free condoms and lubricants. Go visit an STI clinic for condoms!
#3

QUESTION: How long does it take for an STI to show up?
Although this varies, we can usually test for most common STIs two weeks after having sex...
#4

... If you're ever worried about having caught an STI, make an appointment - it never hurts to be cautious!
#5

QUESTION: Will washing the penis or vagina after sex lower the risk of becoming infected with an STI?
Genital hygiene is important and a good practice. 
#6

There is NO EVIDENCE that washing the genitals prevents STI infection. 
#7

In fact, vaginal douching increases a woman's risk of acquiring STIs, including HIV, and pelvic inflammatory disease.
#8

QUESTION: If I had an STI before, can I get it again?
Yes. You can get the same STI multiple times as well as new ones.
#9

QUESTION: Can I take herbal medicine or drink bush tea to cure an STI?
No. STIs can only be treated or cured...
#10
with medication prescribed by a healthcare provider. If you think you have an STI, it is always best to get advice from a health care provider. #11

QUESTION: What are common symptoms of STIs?
- A drip or unusual discharge from sex organ
- Sores, bumps or blisters on or near the sex organs anus or mouth
#12

- Burning pain when you pee or poop
- A swelling or redness in your throat
- Swelling in the area around your sex organs.
- Pain when you have sex 
#12

- Sometimes, you can have STIs with no signs or symptoms. 
- Sometimes the symptoms will go away without treatment but you still have the STIs.
#13

STIs can only be treated or cured with medication prescribed by a  healthcare provider.
#14

QUESTION: Will having sex with a virgin cure someone with an STI, including HIV?
No,, this practice only risks infecting the person who has not yet had sex.
#15

QUESTION: Do you think you have an STI? 
- Please visit a healthcare provider.
- No matter where you get treated, your condition will be kept confidential. 
#16

- Remember to follow your  healthcare provider's instructions carefully and do not share or take medication from other persons.
#17

QUESTION: Where can I get FREE screening for sexually transmitted infections?
Go to your nearest health clinic - or - try to book an appointment here:
#18

Book an appointment here https://jnfpb.org/hiv-test-family-planning/
#19

QUESTION: Are condoms an effective way of preventing sexually transmitted infections for people who are sexually active?
Yes.
#20

Condoms have been proven to provide protection against sexually transmitted infections (STIs). 
#21

FACT: condoms are the only method that can prevent both pregnancy and STIs. 
#22

Condoms provide different levels of risk reduction for different STIs because infections are spread differently: 
#23

some are spread by contact with bodily fluids while others are spread by skin to skin contact.
#24

In general, research shows that condoms are most effective in preventing those STIs that are spread by bodily fluids, such as chlamydia, gonorrhea, and HIV. 
25

Condoms also can reduce the risk of contracting diseases spread by skin-to-skin contact, such as herpes and human papillomavirus (HPV). 
#26

However, condoms only can protect against these diseases if the sores are in areas covered by the condom.
#27

QUESTION: What is the best way to prevent getting an STI?
Abstinence or avoiding sex until both you and your partner have been tested...
#28

...and found NOT to have an STI is the best form of prevention.
It is also best to stick to one partner.
#29

QUESTION: If my symptoms go away without medication does it mean I am cured?
Some STIs will stop showing symptoms, remain in the body and...
#30

... cause more serious problems later on in life. Therefore, it is important to always seek medical advice if you think you have an STI.
#31
